step.value: Artificial intelligence has gotten so good at mimicking human cognition that now we often only see the glitches‚Ä¶
... for example, when autofill presents the wrong words in a text, when Spotify pulls up a dud of a song.
But why do those glitches happen?
And why are machines getting better and better at doing what we do?
To understand how AI works, you have to understand how human cognition works, and recognize all of the processes we take for granted.
The brain is the one part of our body we don't think of as mechanical, but cognition that seems to happen in an instant is actually a series of steps.
In this interactive, we're slowing down the process to show you, step by step, how our brain works.

text.value: Artificial intelligence is transforming the world[a][b]: how we travel, how we communicate, and how we live. But the AI researchers building these tools aren‚Äôt working from scratch. These capabilities take inspiration from how brains learn new things.

btn.text: How do we learn to recognize a scene?
How do we learn to recognize a piece of music?

text.value: Almost half of our brain is devoted to the visual system. Computer vision, the area of AI that deals with how machines see the world, is getting some of the most interest (and funding). To understand how a self-driving car processes a street scene you first need to understand how we see.

visual.title: How does your brain decode a scene?

text.value: After light enters the retina, the scene in front of you is sent from simple visual regions near your eye to more complex ones further into your brain. There is debate in the neuroscience community, but it is likely that early brain systems respond to edges, with single neurons are likely noticing individual edges. This happens even if its a low-contrast situation like a gray car on an overcast evening.
At this point, it‚Äôs almost impossible for either a human or a machine to recognize what‚Äôs in this scene.
From there, some of the 140 million neurons in the visual system start to share and combine different edges to get basic features, like shapes.
Notice how these simple shapes are some of the earliest children learn to name. This is part of the reason why.

After decoding edges and shapes, more complicated aspects like the orientation of objects and their spatial relationships start to become clear. We‚Äôve added a second oval, but it‚Äôs still tough to guess what‚Äôs in the scene.
Notice how your brain starts seeing shapes in relation to each other.

What first looked like an oval now looks like two circles in perspective. Your brain uses a sense of depth and space to help turn a collection of objects into a scene. Here are a few more shapes in a scene.
Can you guess what you‚Äôre looking at?

Your brain has recurrent connections, continuously sending new information back to previous systems. By comparing what you see to what you‚Äôve seen before, you build an understanding of the world. Computer vision also improves by taking feedback and applying it earlier layers of the algorithm.
Now can you guess what‚Äôs in this scene?

Different pathways in your brain light up for scenes than objects, and faces get their own dedicated space in the visual cortex. There might even be neurons that get excited for certain familiar faces, whether a loved one of a celebrity.
Can you guess what‚Äôs in this scene?
Finally, the eyes and AI take in the whole scene. This is all happening in about 200 milliseconds and without any perceived effort by the viewer. Computers take a little longer, but not much.

When we listen to someone speak, our brains make educated guesses about what‚Äôs coming next. Artificial intelligence uses a similar process to predict what words you‚Äôll text next on your phone.

speech.title: This word could save your life

text.value: For our ancestors to adapt and survive, our brain had to establish the relationship between sensory events, like the sounds of speech. And being able to make a guess about what comes next could save precious seconds in life or death situations. To do that, specific neurons in our auditory cortex respond to different phonemes, the smallest units of sound that distinguish one word from another. In English, there are 44 phonemes, like ‚Äúw‚Äù and ‚Äúf‚Äù and ‚Äút.‚Äù
It‚Äôs hard to pick the ‚Äúright‚Äù word without context.
Those groups of neurons learn the relationship between different sounds and the possibility that they go together to predict what might come next.
What word comes next?

AI that predicts text, like the ones that provide the next word in the iPhone‚Äôs messaging app or Gmail‚Äôs new Smart Compose suggestions that tries to guess what you are writing in an email, also relies on understanding relationships. For these AIs, they learn the correlation between letters, words, and sentences after being trained on millions of documents.

speech.title: How AI learns the worst from us

text.value: The problem with training AI on old documents is that it learns human biases. Google Translate used to turn the Turkish phrase ‚ÄúO bir doktor‚Äù into ‚ÄúHe is a doctor,‚Äù despite ‚Äúo‚Äù being a gender-neutral third-person pronoun. Why? The algorithm just saw more examples of doctors being identified as men and learned that relationship. Google now offers up both a ‚Äúhe‚Äù and ‚Äúshe‚Äù translation. A recent study shows how this bias is alive and well in humans‚Äîjust 5 percent of people assume a doctor is a woman, despite making up 44 percent of the profession.

More research into exactly what the brain does might help with dyslexics who struggle to read at speed and are missing the predictive ability. Already, AI-assisted tools like Grammarly are already helping dyslexics fix spelling errors and divining what they meant to write.

We pair music with the most important events in our lives, from hummed lullabies to war drums to weddings hymns to funeral dirges. But what makes a song feel right for a moment or mood? Our brains rely on a combination of hard-wired responses and preferences learned over time to pick the perfect song. Spotify, and other AI-driven music services, start with similar methods but add a whole lot more to build the perfect customized playlist.

Our auditory cortex responds selectively to music-like sounds, but not to speech or non-musical environmental sounds and noises. There are still a lot of unanswered questions, like sorting out if there are other brain regions involved in music processing, and when these systems develop, but it‚Äôs clear that there are some ways that our brains are hard-wired to make sense of music.

music.title: Are my sad songs sadder than yours?

text.value: There is, of course, a major cultural component in how we perceive music, but at least one study shows that we respond to music in similar ways regardless of our background. Researchers had Cameroon tribe members with no exposure to Western culture listen to and label a pop song happy or sad. They could, although their rates weren‚Äôt as spot-on as western participants.

music.title: If you‚Äôre happy and you know it...

text.value: Where does this music fall on a scale from happiest to saddest?

You might have had a sense of how happy a song is even if you haven‚Äôt heard it before, but AI has to be taught. The happiness ‚Äî or lack thereof ‚Äî  of a piece of music is measured with a metric called valence. Songs with high valence, anything above 0.5, sound happier, while tracks below that sound sadder. Spotify had music experts teach an AI the valence of some songs and that algorithm was applied to the rest of the songs on the platform. The rules are a secret sauce but we do know they are fine-tuned regularly.

music.title: An AI playlist just for you

text.value: To put together a Discover Weekly playlist, a unique set of songs that you haven‚Äôt heard but might enjoy, Spotify has three recommendation models they rely on (with some extra rules they hard code in, like no Christmas music after December 25th). One looks at the raw audio for data points like valence, but also the time signature, what key it is in, the tempo, and danceability. Spotify rates a song‚Äôs ‚Äúdanceabilty‚Äù based on including tempo, rhythm stability, beat strength, and overall regularity.

Another Spotify metric compares your listening history to other users. If you and a friend have similar tastes, perhaps your friend might jam to something that you haven‚Äôt heard yet and might like. The final tool looks at the text that includes a song‚Äôs metadata, news articles, blogs, and other written data around the internet. This lets Spotify dig into a song another way to see if two pieces of music are similar and might go well together on a playlist. A non-algorithmic consideration? Playlists put together by everyone from casual listeners to professional playlist makers hired by Spotify. Songs that a user saves on their own playlists are also given more weight.

Why AI sometimes gets it wrong

music.title: The right data, the wrong song

text.value: These very quantifiable recommendations combined with a person‚Äôs harder-to-define taste let Spotify deeply understand songs and pinpoint new oneswhich to uncover for each user. Even with all this data, Spotify can make simple mistakes, like including a song you don't play from an artist that you love, when in reality you just don't like that particular track and tend to skip it.

No matter the taste, music leaves an impression on the brain. According to recent research, the part of your brain that responds to music doesn‚Äôt get lost to Alzheimer‚Äôs. Music that was meaningful to a person can even pull them out of the Alzheimer‚Äôs haze for a short while. Music is what makes us human, and this is proof.
